G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: The Newton Division of the District Court Department has subject matter jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and related provisions because the amount in controversy, exclusive of interest and costs, does not exceed the jurisdictional limit of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court because the incident giving rise to this action occurred at Chestnut Hill Park in Newton, Massachusetts, which lies within the territorial jurisdiction of the Newton Division of the District Court Department. See G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2.

G.L. c. 140, \u00a7\u00a7 136A\u2013174F.proposition: The City of Newton posts signage in the Park requiring that dogs be kept on a leash at all times or in designated areas, consistent with Newton’s municipal leash laws and ordinances.

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, every person owes a duty to exercise the care of a reasonably prudent person under like circumstances to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others. See, e.g., *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146–48 (2006) (general duty of reasonable care; duty to protect foreseeable plaintiffs from harm caused by third parties or instrumentalities under one’s control); *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696–97 (2000) (duty of reasonable care in context of dog‑related injuries).
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.support_reasoning: The court expressly states a general Massachusetts tort principle that every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others, conditioned on recognizable or foreseeable risk. It then applies that general duty to impose on the homeowner a duty to protect a foreseeable victim (a police officer) from harm caused by a third party using a dangerous instrumentality stored on her property. This directly supports both the general duty of reasonable care and its application to foreseeable harm caused by third parties or instrumentalities under one’s control.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.relevant_excerpt: “We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ See Remy v. MacDonald, supra at 677, citing Restatement (Second) Torts § 302 comment a (1965). A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor. … Consequently, with some important exceptions, ‘a defendant owes a duty of care to all persons who are foreseeably endangered by his conduct, with respect to all risks which make the conduct unreasonably dangerous.’”}>>()

*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696\.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, every person owes a duty to exercise the care of a reasonably prudent person under like circumstances to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others. See, e.g., *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146–48 (2006) (general duty of reasonable care; duty to protect foreseeable plaintiffs from harm caused by third parties or instrumentalities under one’s control); *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696–97 (2000) (duty of reasonable care in context of dog‑related injuries).
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696\.support_reasoning: The portion of Glidden v. Maglio provided does not articulate or discuss a general Massachusetts common-law duty that every person must exercise the care of a reasonably prudent person under like circumstances. The court assumes, without deciding, any duty and resolves the case entirely on the causation element, explicitly stating it need not reach whether a duty of care was owed. Thus, Glidden does not serve as authority for the broad duty-of-reasonable-care proposition for which it is cited.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696\.relevant_excerpt: “The motion judge found that the plaintiffs had not shown the requisite control necessary to impose a duty on the defendant. Because the plaintiffs have failed to meet their burden on the issue of causation, we need not decide whether they presented sufficient evidence to show that the defendant owed a duty of care to them sufficient to survive the defendant’s motion for summary judgment.”

*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.raw_text: *Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.*, 408 Mass. 355, 358–59 (1990)
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.proposition: Violation of such statutes and ordinances is evidence of negligence and may constitute a breach of the duty of reasonable care. See *Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.*, 408 Mass. 355, 358–59 (1990) (statutory violations as evidence of negligence); *McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth.*, 429 Mass. 300, 303–04 (1999).
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.support_reasoning: The Court squarely addresses the effect of violating G.L. c. 138, § 69 and reiterates the Massachusetts rule that such a statutory violation does not constitute negligence per se but is only ‘some evidence’ of negligence. That directly supports the proposition that a statutory or ordinance violation is evidence of negligence and may constitute a breach of the duty of reasonable care, depending on the jury’s assessment of the circumstances.
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.relevant_excerpt: “It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979), and cases cited. Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968).”

*McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth.*, 42.proposition: Violation of such statutes and ordinances is evidence of negligence and may constitute a breach of the duty of reasonable care. See *Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.*, 408 Mass. 355, 358–59 (1990) (statutory violations as evidence of negligence); *McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth.*, 429 Mass. 300, 303–04 (1999).
*McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth.*, 42.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the evidentiary effect of statutory (code) violations in a negligence case. The court approves an instruction that a violation of the State sanitary and building codes is evidence of negligence but not conclusive of liability, and explicitly characterizes such violations as evidence of negligence to be considered by the jury. That aligns with the proposition that such violations are evidence of negligence and may constitute a breach of the duty of reasonable care, though not negligence per se.
*McAllister v. Boston Housing Auth.*, 42.relevant_excerpt: “Further, the relevant portions of the codes were read to the jurors, and they were instructed properly that a violation of the codes was to be considered as evidence of negligence. Thus, even though the codes were not introduced in evidence, the jurors were aware of them and their significance… The judge instructed that a violation of a code provision was to be considered as evidence of negligence, but that ‘[i]t should not be taken as conclusive of a breach of the duty of care.’”

*Maillet v. ATF-Davidson Co.*, 407 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, an owner or person in control of a dog must exercise reasonable care to prevent the dog from causing foreseeable harm, including harm resulting from the dog’s menacing or frightening behavior, even if the dog does not actually bite the injured person. See *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. at 696–97; *Maillet v. ATF-Davidson Co.*, 407 Mass. 185, 188–89 (1990) (foreseeable risk of physical harm creates duty of reasonable care).
*Maillet v. ATF-Davidson Co.*, 407 Mass..support_reasoning: Maillet is a products-liability and Chapter 93A case about a defective printing press and failure to warn; it does not involve dogs, animal control, or duties of dog owners. The cited pages (188–89) concern evidentiary rulings and then the scope of c. 93A and breach of implied warranty, not any common-law negligence principle about foreseeable harm from a dog’s behavior. While the opinion generally recognizes a duty arising from foreseeable physical harm in a products context, it does not establish or discuss the specific dog-related duty described in the proposition, so using it for that point is inaccurate.
*Maillet v. ATF-Davidson Co.*, 407 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that ‘the defendant breached its warranty of merchantability in that it failed to warn of dangerous conditions. The machine in its condition was not of merchantable quality. As a result, [the] plaintiff’s hand became caught and crushed by the machine . . . .’ … The judge also took notice of the jury’s conclusion that the defendant was negligent. These findings yield ample factual support for the judge’s holding that the defendant had violated G. L. c. 93A, § 2.”

*Abrams v. Reynolds Metals Co.*, 340 Mas.proposition: To establish negligence under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff must show that Defendant’s breach of duty was a cause in fact and a proximate cause of her injuries. See *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. at 147–48; *Abrams v. Reynolds Metals Co.*, 340 Mass. 704, 706–07 (1960).
*Abrams v. Reynolds Metals Co.*, 340 Mas.support_reasoning: The excerpted opinion is a contract damages case, not a negligence action, and it does not discuss causation in tort terms such as cause in fact or proximate cause. Its analysis focuses on the Hadley v. Baxendale foreseeability rule and the measure of contract damages, not the elements of negligence under Massachusetts law. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition that a plaintiff must show both cause in fact and proximate cause to establish negligence.
*Abrams v. Reynolds Metals Co.*, 340 Mas.relevant_excerpt: "The established principle of law upon which damages for breach of contract may be assessed is that the injured party shall be placed in the same position he would have been in if the contract had been performed, so far as the loss may be ascertained to have followed as a natural consequence of the breach and to have been within the contemplation of the parties as reasonable men as a probable result of the breach. Hadley v. Baxendale, 9 Exch. 341, 354-355."

*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.proposition: Plaintiff’s decision to swerve away from the charging dog was an immediate, reasonable reaction to an apparent and imminent danger of attack, and was a foreseeable response to Defendant’s negligent failure to control his dog. See *Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*, 376 Mass. 101, 105–06 (1978) (foreseeability of plaintiff’s reaction to defendant’s negligence); *Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 Mass. 790, 794–95 (1987).
*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.support_reasoning: Jesionek addresses foreseeability of harm resulting from a third party’s negligent operation of an unsecured forklift, not the foreseeability or reasonableness of a plaintiff’s specific evasive reaction to an imminent danger (such as swerving to avoid a charging dog). The court’s discussion focuses on whether the defendant should have foreseen unauthorized, dangerous operation of the forklift and resulting injury to pedestrians, not on whether the plaintiff’s split-second responsive conduct was itself a foreseeable or reasonable reaction. Thus, it supports general foreseeability of third-party negligence, but not the more specific proposition cited.
*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.relevant_excerpt: “Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable. … It was thus reasonably foreseeable that the forklift, when left unsecured with the keys in the ignition on premises which were solely under the authority’s control, would be operated by unauthorized persons, including inebriated seamen who the authority knew had unfettered access to the cargo area. It was also reasonably foreseeable … that unauthorized operation would likely cause harm to persons known to pass through the area…”

*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.raw_text: *Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 Mass. 790, 794–95 (1987)
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.proposition: Plaintiff’s decision to swerve away from the charging dog was an immediate, reasonable reaction to an apparent and imminent danger of attack, and was a foreseeable response to Defendant’s negligent failure to control his dog. See *Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*, 376 Mass. 101, 105–06 (1978) (foreseeability of plaintiff’s reaction to defendant’s negligence); *Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 Mass. 790, 794–95 (1987).
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.case_name: Solimene v. B. GRAUEL & CO., KG
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.support_reasoning: Solimene is a products-liability case about design defect and superseding cause involving an industrial machine, not about a plaintiff’s immediate reaction to imminent danger or a dog attack. The passages at 399 Mass. 794–95 deal with foreseeability of an employer’s intervening negligence and the general rule that a tortfeasor is liable for foreseeable intervening conduct, not the foreseeability or reasonableness of a victim’s instinctive evasive maneuvers. Thus, while Solimene discusses foreseeability and intervening causes, it does not support the specific proposition about a plaintiff’s swerving reaction to a charging dog.
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.relevant_excerpt: “As a general rule, a tortfeasor is liable ‘for the foreseeable intervening conduct of a third party whether that conduct is negligent or not.’ Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co., 388 Mass. 342, 352 n.10 (1983), quoting Wilborg v. Denzell, 359 Mass. 279, 285 (1971). … The judge correctly left this issue to the jury through appropriate jury instructions.” (399 Mass. at 795).

*Dobos v. Driscoll*, 404 Mass. 634, 640\.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover damages for past and future medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and loss of enjoyment of life. See *Dobos v. Driscoll*, 404 Mass. 634, 640–41 (1989); *Haddad v. Gonzales*, 410 Mass. 855, 871–72 (1991).
*Dobos v. Driscoll*, 404 Mass. 634, 640\.support_reasoning: The excerpted portions of Dobos v. Driscoll focus on liability, supervisory immunity, and governmental immunity, not on the categories of damages recoverable by a plaintiff. There is no discussion in the provided text of what specific elements of damages (medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life) are available under Massachusetts law. Accordingly, this case, at least at pages 640–41 as shown, does not provide authority for the cited damages proposition.
*Dobos v. Driscoll*, 404 Mass. 634, 640\.relevant_excerpt: The provided opinion text around pages 640–41 concerns the plaintiff’s psychological condition and the evidence against the supervisory defendants, but contains no discussion of the types of damages recoverable (medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, or loss of enjoyment of life). Therefore, there is no directly relevant excerpt on that point in this portion of the opinion.

*Haddad v. Gonzales*, 410 Mass. 855, 871.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover damages for past and future medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and loss of enjoyment of life. See *Dobos v. Driscoll*, 404 Mass. 634, 640–41 (1989); *Haddad v. Gonzales*, 410 Mass. 855, 871–72 (1991).
*Haddad v. Gonzales*, 410 Mass. 855, 871.support_reasoning: Haddad is a landlord–tenant/Chapter 93A case focused on emotional distress and warranty-of-habitability damages; it does not articulate a general Massachusetts rule about the categories of tort damages a plaintiff may recover (past/future medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life). The decision discusses emotional distress and diminution in rental value, not the standard suite of personal injury damages, so it does not support the broad proposition for which it is cited.
*Haddad v. Gonzales*, 410 Mass. 855, 871.relevant_excerpt: "On the G.L.c. 93A counterclaim, the judge found that Gonzalez had suffered two discrete injuries as a consequence of Haddad's unfair and deceptive trade practices: emotional distress, and the diminution in value of the apartment due to Haddad's breach of the warranty of habitability.... The judge then placed a value of $18,000 on Gonzalez's emotional distress.... As to the warranty of habitability counterclaim, the judge reasoned that Gonzalez was entitled to the difference between the actual value of the apartment in its defective condition and the fair market value of the apartment..."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: To the extent Defendant contends that Plaintiff was comparatively negligent in reacting to the charging dog, such contention is without merit; however, Plaintiff pleads that, even if comparative negligence were found, it would be less than 51%, and Plaintiff’s damages would remain recoverable subject to reduction pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 85. See *Colter v. Barber‑Greene Co.*, 403 Mass. 50, 62–63 (1988).

*Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co.*, 403.proposition: To the extent Defendant contends that Plaintiff was comparatively negligent in reacting to the charging dog, such contention is without merit; however, Plaintiff pleads that, even if comparative negligence were found, it would be less than 51%, and Plaintiff’s damages would remain recoverable subject to reduction pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 85. See *Colter v. Barber‑Greene Co.*, 403 Mass. 50, 62–63 (1988).
*Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co.*, 403.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely explains that, in Massachusetts negligence actions, comparative negligence under G.L. c. 231, § 85 applies such that a plaintiff’s fault bars recovery only if it exceeds 50%, and otherwise merely reduces damages. The court explicitly rejects importing the ‘unreasonable use’ bar from warranty into negligence because that would conflict with the comparative negligence statute, and notes that the plaintiff’s conduct is to be weighed and can bar recovery only if more than fifty percent responsible. This directly supports a pleading that any comparative negligence less than 51% still allows recovery subject to reduction.
*Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co.*, 403.relevant_excerpt: In a negligence case, the conduct of the plaintiff which will serve to bar recovery is governed by statute. Our comparative negligence statute provides that the plaintiff's contributory negligence shall not bar recovery if the plaintiff's negligence was not greater than the total amount of negligence attributable to the parties against whom recovery is sought. The plaintiff's negligence, if less than the amount attributable to the defendant or defendants, only serves to diminish recovery by the proportion of negligence attributable to the plaintiff. G.L. c. 231, § 85 (1986 ed.). … The plaintiff's conduct … does not bar recovery completely unless the plaintiff is more than fifty per cent responsible for his or her own injuries.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award Plaintiff pre‑judgment and post‑judgment interest as allowed by law, including under G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

G.L. c. 261.proposition: Award Plaintiff her taxable costs of this action pursuant to G.L. c. 261 and applicable rules;
